	The creation of a PM program and ensuring that the POM has specific wording for the maximum fill level for each tank to ensure the probability of overpressure due to overfilling is reduced. To help with this, there are also plans to check records to see how often overfilling occurs (anything above 80%). Refresher training for Emergency Response, MOCs and operations are planned. Tornado and Hurricane training is planned to be included in the Emergency Response program. Also, improving the record keeping and security at the gates are considered to help avoid strangers on-site.

to do so. There are also specific instructions to respond to the release of propane. In the case of propane release, employees are instructed to contact the terminal manager, who will decide whether emergency services will be contacted. Otherwise, employees will evacuate the area, considering the direction of the wind. If safe to do so, activate as many ESDs as possible to stop the process. The yard lead (or next senior operator) must be the last person out (LPO) and will ensure that everyone has left the area. LPO will also take attendance at the muster point once the area is evacuated. 
	All employees are instructed to be familiar with the emergency action plan and are provided with the required training. Emergency drills will be conducted at least quarterly that will run over one of the scenarios mentioned.  
Planned changes to improve safety.
	There are changes being made to improve safety. One is to include a grounding testing program to protect against static electricity build-up. Another is to develop a field assessment and inspection protocol for propane tanks to avoid release scenarios. A procedure for cold temperature shut down procedure due to cold weather in region, as well as an investigation to see how the effective the implementation of a snow drift. Another procedure to manage event of valve not opening. Another change is for the site to develop a hose life cycle replacement program and establish how long a hose can be in use before replacement is required. There are also plans to see if it is feasible to implement a back-up generator to help mitigate the event of loss of power. 
	There are also specific planned changes to help deal with fire scenarios. One is to incorporate hands-on fire extinguisher training in the training procedure. Another is to add to the PSM Program that fire threatens covered process. There are also plans to have the Fire department come to the site and train with the equipment to be familiar with them in case of an emergenc

ario, the first step is to ensure fire alarms are activated. Then all personnel must evacuate the building/area until safe. When a safe distance, personnel will notify 911 and provide the following: Name/Company, the location of site, description of the scenario and if there are any injured persons. Ensure that someone is posted to lead emergency services to the affected area. 
	For an earthquake scenario, if indoors, ensure that you take cover and are away from any structures or furniture that can fall. If outdoors, move away from any structures such as streetlights, buildings, signs, or wires. Vehicles that are in operation are stopped and ensure that you are far from the previously listed structures, as well as overpasses and trees. 
	In case of workplace violence, the priority is to evacuate areas if able to. Employees ensure that no one enters endangered areas and notify authorities at first opportunity. Personnel are instructed to follow police instructions. If evacuation is not possible, employees are instructed to hide in areas that are out of view and provide cover, preferably behind a locked door and with no windows nearby. 
	In case of a bomb threat, employees are instructed to take threats seriously. Employees are told to try to get as much information as possible (location, etc.) and notify the authorities. Ensure that the culprit is kept on the line to get as much info as possible. 
	Employees are instructed to leave the building in orderly fashion in the event of an evacuation and to assemble at muster point when they leave the area. The person stationed at the front desk must get a visitor log and ensure that all visitors have evacuated. Employees are instructed to use the buddy system to ensure that all persons are evacuated and accounted for.
	During hazardous material release, employees are instructed to ensure they have the training and PPE required to respond to the release. Employees can stop the source of release, but only if possible and safe

his system monitors doors and window access in the facility. The propane facility is locked when not in use, and the covered area is located behind fence. The covered process includes bulk tank & appurtenances, liquid line, vapor line, header, hoses, nitrogen system, emergency shutdown systems, information pertaining to the technology of propane, and information pertaining to the equipment in the process. Crowley must update and review procedures and practices annually, as per OSHA standards. Procedures. SDS and Standard Operating Procedures are always readily available to employees. 
The PVE plant was found to fall under Program 3 of the RMP. The worst-case scenario for this plant is a Vapor Cloud explosion caused by the release of 111000 lbs. of liquified propane. The distance to the end point was calculated to be 0.4 miles, with an estimated residential population of 105 within this distance. The alternative case scenario was found to be a pipe break leading to a 10-minute release scenario. This would result in around 7580 lbs. of propane released per min, resulting in a distance to endpoint of 0.1 miles, with there being no residential population in the area. 
	There have been no recorded incidents in the last five years. There has been a history of theft, but no cause for releases or injury has occurred. 
	The PVE facility has a documented emergency response plan that considers several different scenarios. The scenarios are as follows: Medical Emergency, Fire, Earthquake, Workplace Violence/Active shooter, bomb threat and evacuation.
	For a medical emergency, the responder must survey the scene, ask the affected individual for medical history or issues if they are conscious. Responders will send someone to retrieve trauma kit/AED and call 911. When calling 911, employees are instructed to inform the operator of the patient’s name, medical history/issue, symptoms, and location. Responder is expected to stay on the line until dispatchers arrive. 
	For a fire scen

o prevent any leaks/ruptures. The tanks are equipped with pressure gauges and excess flow gauges to avoid overpressure and overfill of propane storage tanks. The facility also has ESD switches to stop the operation of the process.  Propane storage tanks are grounded to avoid build-up of static electricity, which can cause fire and explosion. 
	All utility connections, propane storage, company trucks are behind fences. The facility is equipped with the Guardian Security system, and has employees perform daily walk arounds due to the history of theft. 
	In the event of an accidental release of propane, the procedure instructs to contact Terminal Manager and the decision to decide whether to contact emergency services lies with them. Otherwise, ensure that there is an available path to evacuate area upwind of spill and shut down ESD’s if safe to do so while evacuating. The yard lead will be the last person out and is responsible to ensure everyone is evacuated and present and accounted for at the muster point. In case of fire, the procedure calls on employees to contact 911 when safe and position someone to help guide emergency responders.
	This facility and the covered process fall under the OSHA PSM standard, specifically regulations 29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119. They also fall under the Clean Water Act regulations (40 CFR 112). Propane storage is located above ground and other chemical storage is located underground. 
	The facility documents and records incidents, training, drills, and exercises that occur on site and holds those records for at least 2 years. For training, drills, and exercises, the record will include the date, description, duration, and list of participants. Additionally, the records of the drills and exercises will include a list of best practices lessons learned during the exercise. These records may be kept in electronic form. 
	The facility is surrounded by a six-foot wall fence, and the facility is equipped with the Guardian Security System. T

The Crowley PSM director is responsible for all PSM programs at both the Springer and Parks and Vine (PVE) facilities. The PSM Coordinator is responsible for the implementation of the PSM Programs and ensures proper training and resources are provided to employees. The Facilities maintenance manager will support the PSM Manager and employees in charge of maintenance, inspection, and testing of covered equipment. The Contracted Emergency Services team is responsible for responding to emergencies, evaluating hazards, and ensuring all employees are equipped with proper PPE. They are also responsible for evacuation and search and rescue in the event of emergencies. The Environmental specialist is responsible for tracking recommendations found during audits, PHAs, etc. that pertain to environmental releases or impacts. Finally, the Terminal Manager will be on site and oversee operations while the site is running. There is one Terminal Manager for both sites.
	The PVE Facility is located outside the city of Wasilla, Alaska. The facility contains one propane bulk storage tank, which is used for Bobtail filling operations. Outside of the covered process there are RUL, heating oil, AvGas and ultra-low sulfur diesel contained on site. These are used for delivery to customers and are contained in underground storage tanks located adjacent to the covered process. The PVE site contains 30,000 gallons of propane on-site contained within above ground storage tanks. These storage tanks are located outdoors. The office and shop of the facility are located across from the USTs and Propane loading area.  The propane dispenser and Underground storage units are located adjacent to the main gate. There are two main entrances to the facility: the main gate and the side gate. The side gate is located on the opposite side of the facility from the Main gate.
